page.title: 14The Bridge of Urr
page.content: The bridge is really old. It was first built in 1542 by John McNaught of Kilquhanity for the murder of William Sinclair. It was built from stones from Dryburgh Monastery. The bridge was rebuilt in 1983 because it was not wide enough and a lorry hit the side. When they rebuillt it they left two of the original stones bearing two coats of arms. One is that of King James V and the other is that of John McNaught of Kilquhanity himself. The bridge is the only crossing point from Corsock to the Bridge of Urr. When the river is low you can sometimes stand on a small ledge under one of the arches and you will be able to see a plaque.
